element_texts.text:
Needles. California.
March 1st 1908.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I arrived here this morning
from Ganado. Arizona.
I had fine success until the
Navajo and Moqui Indians
I have disposed of quite a few
of the red drawings I made of
the Navajo and Moqui Indians. 
I have got stored in Chicago
72 oil portraits of Indians
representing the following tribes
Kiowa, Laguna Pueblo, Apache,
Arapahoe, Sioux, Cheyenne,
Yuma, Diegueno, Navajo, Moqui,
Agua Caliente and Soboba.
which I would like to sell.
Now Uncle Ed if you want
these portraits I will sell all
to you for $7.000 and you can
pay me at the rate of $600.00

(2) a year until all are paid for
with no interest.
I am very anxious to make red
drawing of all the American Indian
tribes.
I have now been to 106 different
Indian tribes and am anxious to
finish the job.
The work should be done.
The museums that I have
corresponded with are very anxious
to have the work done but do
not seem to have the money to
spare.
I wish you would write me
soon as you receive this letter. 
You can address me here.
In case you want the portraits
I will give an order to any one
you suggest and they can go
and get them out of the store
house.
Love to you and Aunt Emma.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
3-1-08

Los Angeles. Calif.
June 7th 1908.
My dear Uncle Ed.
You probably know
by this time, that the disagreement
between Mrs B and my self has
been settled and that now I
am free.
I have been at work at
Ganado Arizona among the Navajo's
and now I will return there
in a few days and resume
my work.
I am painting the Navajos
now in oil showing the full figure
I have finished there at Ganado
a Navajo girl sitting among a
lot of sheep pelts in the Hogan
and also finished a picture
showing the Hogan (Navajo house)
with a Navajo man and woman

and little girl outside of the Hogan
and now I am painting there a
Navajo woman weaving a blanket
in a Hogan I am going to
paint a lot a lot of oil pictures now
of Indians doing their native work
and as much as possible in
their native costumes.
If you care for any of them let
me know. I wish I could dispose
of the oil portraits that I have stored
in Chicago.
I have not done much for
the last two years but I think
the work I am doing now will
sell redily as it will be of a
historical value.
I will only make a few red drawings
in the future. I guess I have about
100 red drawings on hand now and
some 70 oil portraits of Indians in
a storehouse in Chicago.
1203

(3)
I had an exhibition here of a lot
of red drawings which created a
good deal of interest, the papers
spoke of them in a flattering way.
I expect you and Aunt Emma
had as usual a fine trip in
Europe.
You can address me to
Ganado. Apache Co. Arizona.
I think Mr Hubbell of Ganado
is going to the Chicago Convention
if he does I wish you could
see him, he is very anxious to
see you and see the Museum and
also see your Navajo blankets.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
6-7-08

July 27th 1908.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I leave here this week for
Polacco Arizona where the Moqui
Indians are 60 miles by wagon
from here.
I am gong to paint the Snake
dance about 30 x 40 inches then
I intend to paint a large picture
from the 30 x 40.
I have fun working in oil here
and have painted a lot of pictures
of these Navajo Indians in all
showing the full figure
Have painted two interiors of Hogans
showing Navajo women weaving
blankets, then I have painted two
16 x 20 pictures one of six Navajos gambling.

at Monte then I limited another 
of nine Navajos gambling at Monte
by fire light.
I probably will be at Polacco
some three months as I expect
it will take that long to paint
the Snake dance. I will paint the
Snake dance from life out doors.
You can address me to
Polacco. Arizona.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
1217

Keams Canon Arizona.
Aug. 11th 1908.
My dear Uncle Ed.
Your letter recived and glad
to hear from  you.
I came over here this evening
horse back from Polacco 11 miles
from here to get some things.
Well I am getting along fine
with the Snake dance picture, there
will be about 50 figures in it
am painting it 30 x 40 and I 
may make a picture 15 x 20 feet
from it. I am showing the whole
Snake dance, every feature that
takes place, am showing the
Antelope men and the snake
men with snakes in their mouths
and Snake men picking up snakes
and also the Moqui girls who
sprinkle meal on the ground

where all the snakes are thrown at
the close of the dance and then carried
away and given their freedom.
Some of the figures will be 18 inches
high and I am painting them direct
from life with full snake dance
costume. The dance I am
painting is located at Walpi
and the buildings and snake
rock I paint on the spot. I am
not going to have any white
people as spectators in the picture
only Indians as spectators.
Every Indian who is a Snake man
has given his consent to sit for
me. The head Chief of the Snake
dance is a personal friend of mine
I have given him shoes clothes
etc at different times and he
shows his gratitude by helping
me with the picture. My room
looks like a Museum as I have
some four or five sets of snake
dance costumes in it. I pay the
Indians $2.00 a day for sitting for
1204

(3)
me for 6 hours a day. I have
now three of the prominent figures
finished. I am going to have
two snakes to sit for me, live
ones a rattlesnake and a bull
snake an Indian said he would
get the two alive for me for
$3.00 I will put them in a box
with on side glass.
I have learned a lot from these
Indians sitting for me about
the Snake dance and I also know
now why the snakes do not
bite them. They have two kinds
of medicines one made from a
root and the other (no white
person knows) but the Indian
said bugs were used in making
it.
While I was at Chico Calif I saw a
root hanging to a nail in the
house and inquired of the Indian
8-11-08

what that was for and he said it
was good for the stomach and he
said when they went after berries
they chewed the root and rubbed
the saliva on their legs and any
kind of a snake ran away from it
on account of the odor.
Now the snake men here do the same
they when in the Keva rub their
bodies over with medicine made
from the root and the snakes do
not bite them on account of the
odor and just before the dance
all the Indians have their bodies
rubbed with this medicine,
a Snake dancer told me this.
I would like to have you see my
work now am painting only
composition pictures.
I wish Uncle Ed the Field
Museum would take me up on
the offer I made them and that
1204

(5)
was to go to every tribe of Indians
living in America and make red
drawings at $10.00 each. It
should be done and you know your
self it is getting late I my self
am 50 years old my my birthday
was yesterday but I feel like I
was 15.
I had made up my mind to go
to Polacco alone and keep house
alone but very next day a
Mr McCormack came to Ganado
he is an Artist from New York
and does work for Century
and Collins and other Magazines
he was on his way to Polacco
to work several weeks so we
live together and do our own
cooking I am a pretty good
cook, since have been with
the Indians had to learn to
cook.
8-11-08

I want to have the Snake dance
picture finished the latter part
of next month.
There will be three snake dances
this year here the first one commences
Aug 20.th
I ought to get a good price for
the Snake dancer picture for it will
be the only one in existence painted
direct from life. I am painting
it very carefully.
You can address me to
Polacca. Arizona.
With love to you and Aunt
Emma and Lizzie and all
relatives.
Your affectionate
nephew.
Elbridge.
1204

Aug 31st 08.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I arrived here last week
Saturday.
I have got the Snake Dance
picture nearly finished, the figures are
finished.
I had to make an oil picture of
the buildings and foreground
on a smaller canvass as the 30 x 40
was too large to work on the
Mesa, so now I am painting the
buildings in the background and
the foreground from the smaller
canvass.
It is almost impossible to get
the Snake men to pose in their
Snake costume up on the Mesa

where the dance takes place, so
I had them all come down to my
house and I painted them there.
I will have the picture completed
this week and I am well pleased
with it. I worked hard on the
picture, did not loose any time.
The Moquis know me by past
experience and they knew that
they had to be on time to pose
for me and they were. They
were much interested in the
picture The old chief of the
Antelope snake men thanked
me for painting it and the
Chief of the Snake men who
put the snakes in their mouths
told me after looking the
picture over carefully that it
was all right.
I have the picture absolutely
correct as far as the dance
is concerned.
I ought to get a big price
for the picture I am thinking
1205

(3)
seriously of painting a large picture
about 10 ft x 14 ft from it.
I have written to Mr Simpson
this and am waiting for his
reply, it would be a fine
advertisement for the Santa Fe
R. R.
The water did not agree with me
at Polacco and just as soon
as the figures were finished
and the picture of the background
and foreground finished. I left for here.  
I do not know how long I
will be here, I want to do some
more work here among these
Navajos

I have quite a few full figures
and groups of figures of these
Navajos one with 9 figures
of Navajos gambling at night
and one with 6 figures in of
Navajos gambling in a Hogan
(Home) and two interiors of a
Hogan showing Navajo women
weaving blankets and some of
Navajo Mothers with the baby
in a cradle etc.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
1205

Los Angeles. Calif.
Sept 4th 1908.
My dear Uncle Ed
I am here now I came
rather unexpectedly.
I was so anxious to see the
Santa Fe people about the
Snake dance picture that I
came now.
The picture is not here yet
but expect it today by Ex
I have been to see Mr. Byrne
of the Santa Fe and had a
long talk with him he is
much interested in the picture
and first wants to see it
before deciding what he will
do. I have been offered already
one thousand dollars for the
picture, but do not care to sell

it for that. I think the Santa Fe
will have me make a large picture
from the 30 x 40 and possibly
make some three color reproductions
from the 30 x 40.
I am to show the picture to Mr
Byrne next week.
I am to have an exhibition here
of my work done among
the Indians recently.
You can address me to
231 S. Hill St.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
1206

Los Angeles. Calif.
Sept 18th 08.
My dear Uncle Ed.
My exhibition is taking
place now and seems well
patronized, people seem to take
an interest in the pictures.
I have got stored in Sibleys
Warehouse, a few hundred baskets
I dont know how many but
they are baskets that I bought
representing every tribe of Indians
who make baskets in California
and Nevada and Arizona.
It is a fine collection and I
picked them out my self and bought
them principally from the Indians
I visited and white people living
among the Indians.
Do you suppose the Field Museum

would want these baskets? If so they
can have them at what they cost me.
I sent you a photograph of the
Snake Dance. The Santa Fe have
not taken the picture as yet. The
picture ought to go to some Museum.
Mr Mandy of the Out West Magazine
wants the Historical Society here to
buy the picture but I would rather
the Field Museum of Chicago would
have it. I dare say the subject will
never be painted again and as far as
I know this picture of mine is the
only truthful painting of the Snake
Dance painted direct from life.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
231 S. Hill. St.
1207

(top R corner) 9/25 Acknowledged 9/25
(top center) Copy to Mr A at Holland House NY 9/25
Los Angeles. Calif. (around 9/29)
Sept 21st. 08.
My dear Uncle Ed.
After my exhibition is over
here I am going to send the
pictures to Chicago to exhibit.
Do you want me to send them
to you first, in case you care
for any of them, you can have
your choice?
The exhibition attracts a lot
of attention here, especially
the Snake dance picture.
Mr George Wharton James was
in to see the exhibition today and he
liked the Snake dance picture
very much.
I am going to send one
of the gambling pictures to

the Art Institute for the Fall
exhibition in Chicago.
If you want me to send the
pictures to you first please let
me know by return mail,
as the exhibition is over the 26th
of Sept.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
231 S. Hill. St.
1208

Los Angeles. Calif.
Sept 24th 08.
My dear Uncle Ed.
Enclose I send you a
letter I received from Prof Holmes
in regard to the Snake dance picture.
I have written to Mr Skiff in
regard to the picture but he has
gone to China so I have written to
Dr Dorsey.
I hope some museum will purchase
the picture.
I sent you a photograph of the
picture. Did you receive it all right?
If so how do you like it?
Some people criticise the Snake
dance picture because no shadows
show from the figures.
The fact is the Snake dance
takes place long after the sun has
settled behind the buildings behind
the dancers, therefore a shadow
is thrown over all the dancers

and it is an utter imposibility for
any figure to throw a shadow on
the ground when that figure is in
shadow.
I painted the picture as concientionaly
as I knew how and studied every
detail minutely.
The Santa Fe R. R. has done nothing
as yet toward buying it.
Let me know if you wish me to
send the pictures to you before sending
them any where else. I think you
would like the pictures of Navajo
women weaving blankets and also
the Navajo Hogan showing all
the Hogan in sun light with
Navajo figures beside the Hogan.
I may possibly sell one of the
Gambling pictures to a man in
Arizona I received a letter from
him this morning asking what I
1209

(3) would take for it.
I have the Snake dance picture
copyrighted.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
231 — S. Hill. St.
9-24-08

Los Angeles. Calif.
Oct 6th 08.
Mr J. A. Faber. 
Chicago, Ill's.
Dear Sir
Yours received
I am sending the pictures to
San Francisco to exhibit and
from there they will go to
Chicago and by that time
Mr Ayer will be home.
Sincerely.
E. A. Burbank.
231 - S. Hill. St.

Oct 14th 08.
My dear Uncle Ed. (arrvd 10/19)
I am back to Ganado
and expect to be here all Winter.
I tried to do some work in Los Angles
but could not get interested in
white subjects so I came here
and will paint a lot of pictures
here this Winter from Indians
mostly composition pictures. 
My Indian pictures at present
are in San Francisco and from
there I will send them to Chicago
let me know if I shall sent them
to you first. I think you will
like the pictures of Indians weaving
blankets.

9 25
unclear--scribbles
You can address me here. 
Your affectionate nephew. 
Elbridge.
1212

Oct 24th 08. 
Mr J. A. Faber. 
Dear Mr Faber
Yours of Oct 19th received.
I thought I had acknowledged
your letter.
After the exhibition is over in
San Francisco I will send the
pictures direct to Mr Ayer to
1 - Banks St.
I am back here for a while
with the Indians.
Very truly yours.

E. A. Burbank.

Oct 26th 08. 
My dear Uncle Ed.
I wish you would go over
to Moulton & Ricketts Art Store
14 to 21 East Van Buren St and
see a picture I have there of
Navajo Indians gambling in a
Hogan (House).
The other Indian pictures are still
on exhibition in San Francisco
and in a few days I will have
them sent to you to 1 - Banks St
for you to look at.
I am making some more
red drawings here of these Navajos
as they are such good types.
I do not know how long I will

be here, but I do not think so very
long.
I hope you and Aunt Emma
had an enjoyable trip East.
How did you like the
photograph of the Snake Dance?
I wish the Field Museum had
the picture. I have written to
both Mr Skiff and Dr Dorsey
but both of them are away
at present.
I have sent the photograph to
several museums but as yet
no sale.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
1214

Nov 12th 08.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I sold the Snake Dance picture
to Mr. Hubble here. I was anxious for
you to see it, but if you want me to
paint another Snake Dance picture
I will do so and make it the same
size as the other one, which was
30 x 40. 
I have written to the Art dealers in
San Francisco to find out when the
exhibition will be over of the pictures
they have of mine and as soon as the
exhibition is over I will have them
sent to you, except the Snake Dance
picture.
If you want a Snake Dance picture
I will go back to the Moquis and
paint another one. I am quite sure

I can get them to sit for me again
but of course it is not certain as
some of them became very tired of
sitting as the pose was difficult
for them, but most of them are
personal friends of mine, any way
I am willing to try.
Mr Lundgren the Artist was here
last week, he has gone to Chin Lee some
36 miles from here and is expected
back here this week. He is painting
landscapes of the “painted desert”
He was very enthusiastic over the
red drawings I made. Mr Hubbell
has quite a number of them.
I am at present painting a picture
in oil of the interior of Mr Hubbell’s
Indian trading store, it is a very
old store. I am painting a lot of
Navajo Indians trading in the store.
I have now a picture of six
Navajos gambling at Moulton &
Ricketts Art store 14 E. Van Buren
St. When you have time wish you
would go and see it. I expect to be
here all Winter.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
1215

Nov 17th 08.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I have ordered the pictures in
oil I have in San Francisco sent to
you by Express to 1 - Banks St.
Now if you miss any of the
pictures you can have them at the
following prices which is less
than I asked for them in S. F.
You can have any of the group
pictures, not including the
gambling picture, for $150.00
each and the single figures
$100.00 each and if you want
the gambling picture you may
have it for $300.00

(3) I wish some time you and Aunt
Emma would come here, you could
come in an Automobile from
Gallup N. M. Mr Cotton at Gallup
has an Automobile, and he has
been out here in it.
You both would not regret the trip.
Mr. Hubbell has a great many
things here that would interest you.
He has a very old collection of
Apache blankets some 300 I should
think.
When you see the pictures that
are sent to you and if you choose
any, what are left I wish you
would please send to Moulton
and Ricketts — 14 East Van Buren
St.

You can charge me with the
Express and other expenses you are
to with the pictures.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
1216

Dec 1st 08. 
My dear Uncle Ed. arrvd 12/7/08
Yours received.
You can have the gambling
picture for $150.00 and you can
send the check here to me here.
I would liked to had you see the
Snake Dance picture but the
photograph gives you a pretty good
idea of it.
When you have the Gambling
picture framed I would suggest
a bronze (dull finish) and no glass
over it.
I am working hard here, painting,
some interiors showing Navajos
I make a few red drawings now
and then so as to have some always
on hand.

A Santa Fe R. R. Official was
here the other day and bought two
red drawings of me.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
1218

answd 12/18
Dec 13th 08.
My dear Uncle Ed.
Yours received with check for
$150.00 enclosed for Gambling picture, which
I thank you for.
As near as I can reckon there are some
200 different tribes of Indians that I
have not made portraits of. There are only
two states that I have made portraits of
all the different tribes living in those two
states, which are California and Nevada
of course I have made portraits of Indians
living in several other states but only
a few tribes of those other states and
some of the important Indians I have
not made portraits of, such as the
Blackfeet, Flatheads, Mandans, Crees
etc etc etc.
If you want me to go ahead and finish
the work I will start right off

and go to Klamath Agency Oregon where
I was when I left off. I would take
each state and work it thoroughly.
I would want to make 20 red drawings
of each tribe men women and children
and that would represent the types thoroughly.
You see if I made but ten red drawings
of each tribe at $6.00 each that would
be $60.00 and many times it costs me
quite a little to get from one tribe to
another.
I am anxious to go on with the work
as I am hardly half through and as
I say if you wish me to I will start
right off and I would not take any
vacation until I was finished.
In Oklahoma alone there are several tribes
I have not made red drawings of and
as well known a tribe as the Nez Perces are
I have made but one portrait of a Nez
Perce and that is Chief Joseph, have not made
any portraits of Nez Perce women at all.
Mr Curtiss the Photographer is taking
photographs of Indians but there are many,
many tribes that he can not get a photograph
of simply because they will not sit for
a photograph as they are so supersticious
of the instrument, while in sitting for me
they know that there is no trick about
it as they can watch me work.
1219

(3) and then a photograph does not give
the type as a careful red drawing does.
While I was at Elko Nevada where the
Shoshonies live that is a branch of that
tribe. I had an awful time to get them
to sit for me but finally got them.
There was a Photographer there who was
taking photographs of Indians but he
could not get a single Shoshonie to sit
for him and he wondered how I got them.
The same among the Acoma Indians
while I was there the Agent there told
me that there was no use of me
staging them as he said no one could
get a picture of them, but inside of
fifteen minutes I had an Indian sitting
for me in the Agent’s own house.
I have been now to 113 different
tribes of Indians and I have made

portraits of every one of them. Some I
admit I had a time with.
Hoping to hear from you soon and
that you will want me to start
out again.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
P. S. I wish you Aunt Emma
and Lizzie and family
a Happy Xmas.
1219

Dec 23rd 08.
My dear Uncle Ed. arrvd 1/6
Yours received.
In my letter to you I estimated
that there were some 200 different
tribes of Indians that I had not
made portraits of, of course there may
be less than that number.
If you wish to have me go on
with the work and make ten
portraits of each tribe in the red
drawings at $6.00 a portraits I will
go and in case there are 200 tribes
that would be $12000.00.
I made a rough estimate and I
am willing to go and make ten
portraits of each tribe, which would
represent that tribe well.

I could make some oil portraits of
some of the tribes I went to, which
would pay me.
If there were more than 200
tribes I could keep you posted
and confine my self to 200
tribes, the chances are there are less than
200 tribes.
I am anxious to go and if you
want me to go now and
make 10 portraits of each tribe,
let me know and I will start
soon as hear from you.
Hoping to hear from you soon.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
1220

Jan 5th 09.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I wrote you a few days ago
and wrote that if you wanted me
to go out among the Indians and
finish making red drawings of the
remaining tribes and make ten red
drawings of each tribe I would go.
I wish you would please let me know
soon as you can if you want me
to go as if I am not going I
can make my plans.
Do you remember when you sent the
pictures I sent you to send to
Moulton & Ricketts 14 E. Van Buren St.?
I have not heard from them as yet
in regard to the pictures and I have
written them twice.
Hoping to hear from you soon.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.

Ganado. Arizona.
Jan 11th 09.
My dear Uncle Ed.
Yours of Jan 6th at hand
and contents noted.
You certainly have done your share
in regard to perpetuating the Indian,
in the Indian curios you have collected
and the Library on the Indians you have and
the Indian portraits I have made for
you.
If some Museum wanted me to go
out among the Indians I would have
to charge them at least $10.00 for each
portrait in the red drawing.
If the work is not done soon, it
will be too late as the Indians are
becoming more civilized every year
getting their hair cut etc and thus so
many tribes are extinct.
I see there are some 14 different tribes
living in Alaska and two tribes there
are extinct now.
Then too I am getting along in years,
and in a few years I will be too
old to go, to stand the hardships
that one must go through to live

among the Indians as one must do in
order to get their portraits, then too
I may settle down in some Studio
some where.
I have written to several Museums, they
wrote me nice letters and are very
anxious to have the work done but
have not the means.
I think you will agree with me that if
in years to come, letters of mine happen
to be on file in some Museum where in I offered to
visit every tribe of Indians and
make red drawing portraits at $10.00
each of each tribe, those who are in charge
will regret very much that the work
was not done when not too late.
I will remain here for some time yet.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
1222

Jan 16th 09.
My dear Uncle Ed.
Yours of Jan 12th received
and contents noted.
I will start out any time you want
me to and make the 275 red drawings
for you and I only would make red
drawings of Indians I had not been to.
How do you like this envelope?
I designed it for Mr Hubbell. The
portrait was taken from a red drawing of
mine.
Hoping to hear from you soon.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.

Mr Edmond E. Ayer.
Railway Exchange Bldg.
Michigan Ave.
Chicago. Illinois.

arrvd 1/29
Isleta. N.M.
Jan 25th 1909.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I received your letter
last Friday and the next
day I started for here and
arrived here this morning
and am having good
luck with these Isleta
Pueblo Indians.
It is the first time I have
been here. They speak a
different langague from
the Laguna Indians and are
the cleanest Indians I have
as yet been to, there are
1000 of them here.

I will not make any

Jemez. N. M.
Jan 20th 09.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I arrived here all right
after twelve hours of long
cold ride by wagon from
Albuquerque.
I thought at first I would
have to sleep on the floor in
the store and eat canned
goods and crackers from
the store, but I have a nice
room with a fire in the room
and a nice place to eat.
I will have good luck here.
These Jemez Indians
are a distinct tribe by
themselves speak a different

language and there are
500 of them here, living
in the mountains.
They are a fine looking
Indians so manly looking
they live in adobe houses
in a village but years ago
they lived up on the Mesa.
Nine miles from here living
on a Mesa are the Sia
Indians, they tell me that
years ago there were 30,000
Sia Indians now there
are scarcely 100. The Sia
Indians and Jemez Indians
do not speak the same Tongue 
therefore they converse with
each other in Spanish.
I will go to the Sia Indians
from here.
Last night at Albuquerque
I met Mr Schweizer

who has met you, he is
manager of the Indian department
at Albuquerque in the Alvardo
Hotel for Harvey and no
man is better posted on
the Pueblo Indians in
New Mexico than him and
I had a long talk with him
and he gave me the names
of 19 different Indians
where they live and how to
get to them in New Mexico
and I will visit them all.
They end at Taos. N.M.
Then I go to Colorado.
Mr Hubbell is pretty well
posted on the Indians in
N. M. but not as well
as Mr Schweizer.
When I return to Albuquerque
I will send you what
red drawings I have for

you to Railway Exchange
Bldg.
I got some fine types at
Isleta. N. M.
You know living with the
Moqui Indians at first
Mesa are a tribe of Indians
called the Tewa's. They
originally came from near
Taos. Their deserted
village is still there in ruins.
They all went to Arizona
and lived in a separate
village on the same Mesa
that the Walpi Indians
live on. You have some red
drawings of them. They left
this country some 250
years ago.
I met a man here who told
me where the deserted village
is.
I expect you have been through

(5) this country years ago horseback.
The Jemez hot springs are 15 miles
from here.
I expect to have a lot of trouble in getting
the San Domingo Indians to sit for me.
An Artist was there some time ago and
he could do nothing with them and they threatened
to kick him out. Well they will have a
chance to kick me out, but I will not leave
until I have ten red drawings of them.
There generally is some crank of an old
Indian that makes trouble and tells
the others, I had trouble with just
such a fellow at Isleta, he came to my room
on purpose and commenced to make
trouble but before he left the room I
won him over and he promised to sit
but he did not, but kept out of sight
and did not bother me any.
I will write you again later on.
You can address me to Domingo New.
Mexico.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.

Jemez. N. M.
Jan 29th 1909.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I am having good success
with these Indians.
They have good land here and
have an irrigating ditch which they
keep in repair them selves.
They raise corn wheat chile vegetables
etc and make the crudest basket
I ever saw and make no pottery.
There is an old man here by the name
of Miller, he knew Thomas Keam
when he was a boy here in this
country and the old man has lived
with these Jemez Indians for years.
He told me today that these men two
Indians here from the Pecos tribe that
was supposed the tribe was extinct.
They are both old men and all that
is left of the Pecos tribe.
I will get both of them to sit for me
when am through with the Jemez

Indians.
Mr Miller told me the same that
Schweizer did that there are 19 East of
Isleta different Pueblo Indians in N. M.
but these Pecos Indians makes
20.
These Indians give a dance tomorrow.
These Indians are very clean in their
homes. They have no sheep at all
but depend upon their crops for a
living.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.

Jemez. N.M.
Feb 1st 09.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I leave for Zia tomorrow
a Pueblo nine miles from here.
There is only one Pecos Indian
living the other one was a half breed
so I made a portrait of the one.
These Jemez Indians have a whole
lot of good common sense.They
have three irrigating ditches and
have plenty of water. They have a Governor
who is the boss.
They are now cleaning out their ditches
half the Indian men work one day and
half the next day.
They raise Grapes and Peaches here.
They have laws, and they enforce
them. They have dances called Secret
dances and no white man is allowed
to see it and they see also that he does
not see it, they have Indians stationed
around to watch.

I am getting some fine types here.
The are a different type than the
Isleta and can not understand
each other at all neither can they
speak the Zia langague.
I expect I will have to live with
the Indians at Zia but they are
clean and I do not mind it.
I have had fine luck so far in
getting these Indians to sit for me
but I anticipate a lot of trouble
with the San Domingo Indians, for
some reason they object strongly
to haveing a picture made of the.
One Artist was there a few years
ago and he made a picture on
the sly of their village showing
some of the Indians and he had to
leave the place, but I will get them
all right.
These Indians are certainly industrous
both men and women and are well
fixed and live in a beautiful
country. The Jemez river runs by
their village and they have three
irrigating ditches.
Prof Holmes was here some 20
years ago and did some work
1227

(3)
here.
I think you will like the red drawings
I am making now better than any
you have.
This work I will send you by Express
to Railway Exchange Bldg. red
drawings representing the Isleta,
Jemez, Pecos and Zia Pueblo
Indians.
I will arrive in Albuquerque Thursday
night and next morning I go to
Bernalilo N. M. but you can
address me to Domingo. N. M.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.

Feb 3rd 09.
My dear Uncle Ed. 
I have been out to the

They are different from these

Bernalillo. N.M. Feb 6th 1909.  My Dear Uncle Ed.  I have had my first trouble with the Pueblo Indians today.  This morning I hired a team and went ten miles to the San Anna Indians, before going I got the names of two San Anna Indians that speak English and went to the house of one of them and told him what I came for and showed him some red drawings of Ishto Jemez and Zia Indians he recognized them and asked me if I had permission of The San Anna Indians Sorcerer.  I told him not yet, he said you will have to see him so he sent for him The minute I saw him I knew I would have trouble, he is a big Indian unlcear and crass? unlcear.  I showed him the red drawings and explained things to him.  He asked me if I had permission to come to their

village and make portraits of the
San Anna Indians from Mr
Perry the Indian Agent (who is a
friend of mine) I told him no, well he
says you can not make any pictures
of these Indians unless you show me
a letter from him authorizing you too.
I told him I had made portraits of
117 tribes of Indians and been 12
years at it and I never had any
permission except from the Chief's
and Governors of the Indians before
and he was the first Indian to talk
that way I also told him that
I had supposed the Governor had
more to say about his own tribe
than any white man on Earth, but
he was obstinate and no argument
of mine would change his mind, so I
had to leave. but I am going to
telephone over to Mr Perry at Albuquerque
and have him write me a letter good
for all Pueblos under his jurisdiction
and am going to write Mr Crandel
Agent for the rest of the Pueblo Indians
who is at Santa Fe.
I showed the Governor the portrait I
had made of the Governor at Zia
1230

(3)
and told him he was only too glad
to have his picture made and also
his Indians, but it was no use.
It is just as well for there is not a
single white person living at
San Anna and the old Indian
woman was preparing Dinner and I
thought if I have to eat that I am
certainly up against it.
The San Anna Indians have a
farming village two miles from here
and they told me that in four
days they were all going to the
farm village, women children and men
to work on the farms and they told
me as soon as I got the letter from
Mr Perry they would sit for me
so I probably will get the letter
tomorrow.
San Dia is three miles from here
and San Felipphi is eight miles
from here so I will stop at a
Hotel here and go horse back to
these three villages.
2-6-09

the San Anna are a fine type of an

I will get them all right.
Their farms are side of the Rio Grande
River where they irrigate.
I will go to San Dia Tomorrow.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.

San Felippi. N.M. Feb 9th 09. My Dear Uncle Ed I arrived here at noon and am getting along all right.  These Indians live in quite a large Pueblo side of the Rio Grande River.  They are still different from the other Pueblos I have been to, they are a larger Indians especially the men.  The younger men have their faces painted all the

and wear bright colored
blankets.
They seem to be very
well fixed by the loos
of their village and they
have fine rich land
Two San Felippi Indians
who speak English were
in to see me this eve".
San Domingo is only six
miles from here and these
two Indians have been telling
me of those Indians
According to them the
San Domingos must be
a hard lot.
They will not allow
a white man in their
village with a Camera
1232

They take the camera away from him and break it, but I will go there after am through with the Santa Anna Indians but I wont have any Camera with me.
They used to have a School but they treated the School teacher so mean that the Government took the School away from them and now they have to send their children to Albuquerque to School.

I am quite sure I will get what pictures I want of them all right. These Indians have secret dances where no white man is allowed to see.
They make ? ?.
You can address me to Domingo. N.M.
Your affectionate nephew,
Elbridge.

My dear Uncle Ed,

Every Indian has sat for me that I have ? and some asked me to make pictures of them.

The Santo Indians bought 400 acres of land years ago and it is fine lived? land and their irrigate it all from the Rio Grande River. During the Winter they live in their Winter village some 10 miles from here and when they are away they hire a Mexican to watch their Summer village. They have comfortable homes in their Summer village. There are some very pretty girls among them.
The San Felippi Indians told me that there were some very pretty girls

among the Domingo Indians. I leave for Domingo by ?s Sunday morning some 16 miles from here and there I expect my trouble will commence but I will hang to them until I get the portraits. Tesuque. N. M.
Feb 23rd 1909.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I am through with the
Tesuque Indians, They are as nice
Indians as I have been to, the old
Governor is a fine old man and has
good sense, he was the first to sit for
me. The Tesuque Indians live nine
miles from Santa Fe and there are very
few of them and their village is small
They have fine land and irrigate from
a creek that runs by their village.
I got some fine types of them as I had
my pick of the lot.
I noticed in the Governors house
a cane presented to the Tesuque village
by Lincoln.
I heard here who the Domingo Indians

are so down on the Government and
white people in general. It is on account so
I am told of the Tiffany Turquoy mines
which is 14 miles from Domingo and
the Domingo Indians claim it. There is
a good deal of trouble over the mines, The
Miners have to be around all the time on
account of the Domingo Indians and
two of the Domingo Indians have to appear
in Court soon on account of throuble there.
Tomorrow a Tesuque Indian takes me
to the Nambe Indians some three hours
ride by wagon. I will have to travel
some 150 miles by wagon to reach all
of these Indians around here.
These Indians make fine pottery
some of it is black and a fine finish.
You can address me to
Ignacio. Colorado.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.

My dear Uncle Ed

These Indians have the cleanest and

Penasco. N. M.
Mch 4th 09.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I arrived here last night.
This place is 40 miles from San Juan
and it is the most hidden and
out of the way place I have been to.
The Pecuris Indians are here and
they are a pretty poor lot. They live in
one of the most interesting villages I
have been to, there are 135 Indians here
and they have poor land but plenty
of water to irrigate with. There is an
old ruin here which looks like an
old Castle. it resembles the old ruin
at Casa Grande near the Pima
Indians at Sacaton Arizona.
These Indians say that long times
ago many of their people went
West and that five men and five
women went East and one man
and one woman remained here and
that the present Indians are
descendants from these two.
I am having good success in

getting them to sit for me
This village is so hard to get to, one has
to cross a mountain in order to get
here that very few white men and
other tribe of Indians very seldom come
here, I feel sorry for them they are so
poor some of them go around dressed
in rags.
I was told they speak the Tewa
langague but they say they do not
and I noticed that the San Juan
Indian who brought me here
and who speaks Tewa could not
talk to these Picuris Indians so
he conversed in Spanish with them.
They can barely understand the
Taos Indians who are their
nearest Indian neighbors and
who live 25 miles from here across
a mountain.
They are fine types and I have
my pick of them to sit for me.
I will have to leave here horseback
with an Indian guide and a pack
animal to carry my things to Taos

(3) as the wagon road across the
mountain to Taos is such a bad
steep road that they seldom go there
by wagon.
These Indians wonder when their
people went to that went East
and West I have heard that these
are Picuris Indians living with
the Isleta Indians, they used to have
their own village near Isleta but they
were so reduced in numbers that
they went and lived with the
Isleta's. They think that the
Indians that went West went
to California which I believe and
probably went to Southern California
as down then I have been to a tribe
that live in adobe houses similar
to this village.
They have their own langague but
say they can understand the
Isleta and San Dia Indians
langague.
I am stopping with the School
Teacher and he seemed glad to
have me with him, He said I was

the first white man he has seen
for seven months and that he

Taos. N. M.
Mch 8th 09.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I am through with the
Taos Indians and got some fine
types here. I had quite a time to
get them to sit for me but got
them all right.
They are the best fixed of any of the
Pueblo Indians in New Mexico.
They were smart enough not to
sell any of their land and they
have fine land and all the water
they can use to irrigate with and
do not allow no Mexican or white man to live on their land
They are absolutely different from
any tribe I have been to and remind
me so much of the Sioux Indians.

painted are the time that is the
men. They live in two large villages,
a stream of water divides the village

and both villages are under one Governor
An old ex Governor sat for me.
They will not allow any modern
windows in their adobe houses, so they
have a hole about a foot square
for a window and no glass in
the window. They are very primative
and wear no hats and comb their
hair just like a Sioux.
They have the finest horses I have
seen among the Pueblo Indians of
New Mexico. The women are not as
good types as the men.
They do not speak the Tewa
langague as I had always heard
they did.
This completes all the Pueblos
in New Mexico.
There is quite a colony of Artists here
Two noted Artists live here all
the time and some New York
Artists have houses here and come here

Ignacio. Colorado.

My dear Uncle Ed.
